resource.chars: As long as your generosity lasted,
That you would leave me to bear my great pain
Forever, without comforting me,
Or without having any distraction
From you, for the sake of whose love I bear it,
So much do I hope for your forgiveness in love [?].
May the eyes in your bright face be cursedâ€”
Which began to move so sweetly
Towards me when they were forced to look at me.
Therefore if your very kind gaze
Had to draw me towards you,
Through the sweetness that I felt there,
When I sought refuge near you for assistance,
If sweetness leaves you
About your sweet gaze, treason!
My lady, if this is the way it is, without a debt,
That in you sweetness is lacking towards me,
I have a right to pursue a suit against you,
My lady; know that my accusation
Would be of treachery,
For where is there a greater misdeed
Than in completely drawing in a man towards oneself
By making sweet, attractive glances,
And afterwards, when he is caught in the trap,
And the miserable, poor man is taken,
Leaving him to languish in this state
Without giving him any assistance at all?
This would be cruelty, certainly!
As long as, of a person of great beauty,
Such calumny could be spoken,
As of you, in cruelty
May it never come to pass
But certainly it will not.
For it is commonly said
That mercy must be stationed
In a heart of noble feeling.
For this reason, it cannot be the case at all,
Certainly, that [such a heart] does not remain in you,
For according to what resembles
Your sweet, loving face,
A noble, well-tested heart
Must, according to rights, be found in you.
And because of the example
That I am able to find in your sweet face
Which reassures me with its sweetness,
My hope is very certain
That your generous heart full of friendship
Will have pity on me again,
Because of this, gracious one,
I relinquish as of this moment,
For as long as I will live,
The right to file a suit against you
And to live in another way, at the end,
Except that all of my rewards are in you.
And as someone who desires ardently
To have help in his pain,
Whose heart is darkened and blackened
Sweet, well made, charming and delicious,
Pleasant, beautiful and graceful one,
Sovereign in intelligence and beauty,
Fountain of honor and valor,
In whom sweetness and concord live,
As well as pity and graciousness,
Of all beauty, the lily and the rose,
Lady in whom as much grace is enclosed
As there is water in the sea,
Generous, loving heart, without bitterness,
With joined hands, I would like to pray
That you not desire to push away
The mercy that must come to me through you.
And may God grant that you be reminded
And that it please you that I be granted
That you have pity on me,
Since I am, ladyâ€”know thisâ€”
Anchored and attached
With my whole heart in love for you,
So that on no road or path
At any time is my attention not directed
Towards pleasant service for you.
I do not want to direct it anywhere else,
However much I must suffer.
I must sigh and complain,
Moderate my heart and darken my complexion,
For, my very sweet, dear lady,
With all pains and all suffering put behind me,
Good hope, through which a lover
Relieves himself of his anguish, comforts me,
And gives me the will
To abandon heart and body completely
Without holding anything back
In order to endure and sustain,
For your sake, the sweet pains of love
Which are so sweetly delectable
To me, and pleasant to feel,
That I do not wish to repent for them ever,
Rather I would like to give in to them completely
Even if I do not feel certain,
Even though hope leads me in this direction,
That from my service, lady,
I will obtain a sweet reward in the end.
Now may it be fitting, my sweet kind lady,
Completely, in entirety, with no reservation,
Nor exception, nor reserve,
In the highness and great worth
Of your sweet heart full of generosity,
To command, according to your desire,
As if for your serf and liegeman,
That I, who loyally serve you
â€”if it pleases youâ€”
Receive as a gift, through heartfelt feeling,
Your sweet, simple and pretty love,
Even though I am not worthy
To receive such a very valuable gift,
In consideration of my worth. But if, truly,
If it happens that
Your sweetness and your grace act so that
Your sweet heart is brought to this,
Through mercy for me that would overcome you,
Or if it pleases you to leave me
In this way, without resigning yourself to
Your sweet help assisting me
With the pains in which I still languish,
My heart captive in your prison,
And of which I will never obtain the cure,
If pity does not make you agree
To have mercy on me,
For whatever it might please you to do
â€”To leave me in this suffering
To live or to languish as a martyr,
Or if it might be enough for you,
What I have endured and endureâ€”,
May it not go on any longer
That you not bring me assistance;
And I want you to know well,
My lady, that as long as I have to live,
Whatever should happen afterwards,
In the same way as I have done until now,
And as a true lover must do:
